title: Heme Catabolism
subject: Biochemistry
description: Questions about heme catabolism, bilirubin metabolism, and related disorders.

questions.questionText: Approximately how many grams of hemoglobin does the human body turn over per day?
questions.explanation: Human turns over approximately 6 g of hemoglobin per day.

questions.questionText: From 1 gram of hemoglobin, approximately how many milligrams of bilirubin are produced?
questions.explanation: It is estimated that 1 g of hemoglobin yields 35 mg of bilirubin.

questions.questionText: What is the estimated daily bilirubin formation in human adults?
questions.explanation: The daily bilirubin formation in human adults is approximately 250–350 mg.

questions.questionText: Which system is primarily responsible for the first stage of bile pigment formation, involving the breakdown of worn-out erythrocytes?
questions.explanation: The formation of the bile pigments can be divided into 3 stages: I- In reticulo-endothelial system (RES).

questions.questionText: After approximately 120 days, worn-out erythrocytes are taken up by reticulo-endothelial cells mainly located in which organs?
questions.explanation: After approximately 120 days in the circulation, the worn out erythrocytes are taken up by the reticulo-endothelial cells, mainly in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

questions.questionText: What happens to the globin portion of hemoglobin in the reticulo-endothelial system?
options: It undergoes proteolysis into amino acids
It is conjugated with glucuronic acid
questions.correctAnswer: It undergoes proteolysis into amino acids
questions.explanation: The globin is removed and undergoes proteolysis into amino acids.

questions.questionText: How is bilirubin transported from the reticulo-endothelial system to the liver?
questions.explanation: Bilirubin is only slightly soluble in plasma and, therefore, is transported to the liver by binding non-covalently to albumin.

questions.questionText: Why cannot unconjugated bilirubin normally be excreted in urine?
options: It is too large a molecule
It is rapidly metabolized by the kidneys
It is bound to plasma proteins (albumin)
It is actively reabsorbed by the renal tubules
questions.correctAnswer: It is bound to plasma proteins (albumin)
questions.explanation: Bilirubin is only slightly soluble in plasma and, therefore, is transported to the liver by binding non-covalently to albumin. Thus it cannot be excreted in urine.

questions.questionText: If plasma bilirubin levels exceed the albumin carrying capacity (about 20 mg/dL), unconjugated bilirubin can pass the blood-brain barrier due to its hydrophobic nature, leading to what condition?
questions.explanation: If the plasma level of this bilirubin exceeds the carrying capacity of albumin (about 20 mg/dL), it passes the blood brain barrier (due to its hydrophobic nature) and produces brain damage or “kernicterus”.

questions.questionText: What is the name given to the chief bilirubin in the blood, which is transported bound to albumin?
questions.explanation: It is the chief bilirubin in the blood, and hence the name “hemobilirubin”. Hemobilirubin is also called unconjugated bilirubin.

questions.questionText: What is the primary enzyme responsible for conjugating bilirubin with glucuronic acid in the liver?
questions.explanation: Conjugation of bilirubin with glucuronic acid... is catalyzed by the enzyme glucuronyltransferase.

questions.questionText: What molecule provides the glucuronic acid residue for bilirubin conjugation?
questions.explanation: Glucuronic acid... Supplied by UDP-glucuronate is catalyzed by the enzyme glucuronyltransferase.

questions.questionText: What is the final product of bilirubin conjugation in the liver, which involves the addition of two glucuronic acid residues?
questions.explanation: A glucuronic acid residue becomes connected to the carboxyl group of one, then the second, propionate side chain of bilirubin, forming bilirubin diglucuronide.

questions.questionText: Conjugation of bilirubin primarily increases its:
questions.explanation: Conjugation increases polarity and water-solubility of bilirubin (now its water soluble).

questions.questionText: Which of the following is listed as capable of inducing the enzyme glucuronyltransferase?
questions.explanation: Glucuronylansferase is induced by drugs, e.g. phenobarbital, and by glucose.

questions.questionText: What is the principal route of excretion for conjugated bilirubin?
questions.explanation: Excretion of conjugated bilirubin Is principally through the bile.

questions.questionText: What is conjugated bilirubin often called, referencing its primary excretion route?
questions.explanation: Excretion of conjugated bilirubin Is principally through the bile, and hence the name “cholebilirubin”.

questions.questionText: Which type of bilirubin can be excreted in urine due to its water-soluble nature and lack of binding to plasma proteins?
questions.explanation: Being water-soluble, conjugated bilirubin is not bound to plasma proteins, thus it can be excreted in urine. Unconjugated bilirubin is bound to albumin and cannot be excreted in urine.

questions.questionText: What is considered the rate-limiting step in bilirubin metabolism?
options: Uptake of unconjugated bilirubin by liver cells
Conjugation of bilirubin with glucuronic acid
Secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile
Absorption of urobilinogen from the intestines
questions.correctAnswer: Secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile
questions.explanation: Secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile occurs by an active transport system. This is the rate-limiting step in bilirubin metabolism.

questions.questionText: In the large intestine, by the action of intestinal bacterial flora, bilirubin is released from glucuronic acid and undergoes successive reductions ending in the formation of a colorless product known as:
questions.explanation: In the large intestine, by the action of intestinal bacterial flora, bilirubin is released from glucuronic acid and undergoes successive reductions ending in the formation of colorless stercobilinogen, also known as urobilinogen.

questions.questionText: What is the main pigment of feces, formed by the spontaneous oxidation of stercobilinogen by the oxygen of air?
questions.explanation: The stercobilinogen is spontaneously oxidized by the oxygen of air to the brown stercobilin, the main pigment of feces.

questions.questionText: Urobilinogen, partly absorbed from the intestines, is returned to the liver via which blood vessel system?
questions.explanation: Urobilinogen, is partly (small percentage) absorbed from the intestines and returned, via the portal blood, to the liver (enterohepatic circulation).

questions.questionText: What is the typical normal range for urobilinogen excretion in urine per day?
questions.explanation: Little urobilinogen normally escapes to the systemic circulation and is excreted in the urine (0.5 to 4 mg/day).

questions.questionText: What is urobilinogen converted to on exposure to air in urine?
questions.explanation: Little urobilinogen normally escapes to the systemic circulation and is excreted in the urine... where it is converted to urobilin on exposure to air.

questions.questionText: The enzyme Heme oxygenase, found in the RES, catalyzes the cleavage of the alpha-methenyl bridge of heme, producing biliverdin, Fe3+, and what gas molecule?
questions.explanation: RES Heme oxygenase (produces cleavage of -methenyl bridge) produces Biliverdin, NADP+, Fe3+, CO.

questions.questionText: What is the color of Biliverdin?
questions.explanation: Biliverdin (Green) is converted to Bilirubin (Yellow).

questions.questionText: The enzyme Biliverdin reductase converts Biliverdin to Bilirubin using which cofactor?
questions.explanation: Biliverdin (Green) Heme Biliverdin reductase NADPH,H+ converts to Bilirubin (Yellow) NADP+, Fe3+, CO. The arrow shows NADPH,H+ being used.

questions.questionText: The Van den Bergh reaction is a method used to estimate the level of what substance in blood?
questions.explanation: Serum bilirubin can be estimated by the Van den Bergh reaction.

questions.questionText: In the Van den Bergh reaction, which type of bilirubin reacts rapidly with the reagent in aqueous solution without the addition of a solvent?
questions.explanation: In aqueous solution, the water-soluble, conjugated bilirubin (as it is not bound to Albumin) reacts rapidly with the reagent (within one minute), and is said to be “direct-reacting.”.

questions.questionText: What does 'indirect-reacting' bilirubin, as measured by the Van den Bergh method, correspond to?
questions.explanation: The indirect-reacting” bilirubin, which corresponds to the unconjugated bilirubin, is obtained by subtracting the direct-reacting bilirubin from the total bilirubin.

questions.questionText: What is the normal total serum bilirubin range in mg/dL?
questions.explanation: Normal total serum bilirubin ranges between 0.2-1.2 mg/dL.

questions.questionText: Jaundice is defined as the yellow color of skin, nail beds, and sclerae caused by the deposition of bilirubin, secondary to increased bilirubin levels in the blood. What is another term for jaundice?
questions.explanation: Jaundice (also called icterus) refers to the yellow color of skin, nail beds, and sclerae caused by deposition of bilirubin, secondary to increased bilirubin levels in the blood (hyperbilirubinemia).

questions.questionText: An elevation of serum bilirubin above what level typically leads to visible yellowish discoloration (jaundice)?
questions.explanation: Elevation of serum bilirubin above 2 mg/dL leads to yellowish discoloration of the skin, sclera and mucous membranes, a condition known as jaundice, icterus, or hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.questionText: Values of serum bilirubin between 1.2-2 mg/dL are considered what type of jaundice?
questions.explanation: Values between 1.2-2 mg/dL are considered latent jaundice.

questions.questionText: According to the handout, jaundice is classified based on the predominant form of bilirubin in the serum. Which type is characterized by mainly indirect bilirubin?
questions.explanation: According to the predominant form of bilirubin in serum, jaundice is classified into: (a) Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, (b) Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and (c) Both unconjugated and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (mixed type). Serum bilirubin increases, mainly indirect bilirubin in Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia, specifically Hemolytic jaundice.

questions.questionText: In hemolytic jaundice, which form of bilirubin primarily increases in the serum?
questions.explanation: In hemolytic jaundice, there is increased hemolysis... Serum bilirubin increases, mainly indirect bilirubin.

questions.questionText: Which of the following findings is typical in the urine of a patient with hemolytic jaundice?
questions.explanation: In hemolytic jaundice... Urobilinogen increases in the urine.

questions.questionText: Hemolytic jaundice is also known as "acholuric jaundice." What does "acholuric" mean?
questions.explanation: Since unconjugated bilirubin is bound to the plasma albumin, it cannot be excreted in the urine, and hence the name “acholuric jaundice”. (Acholuric: A= no, chole= bile, uric= urine). 'Bile' here refers to bile pigments like conjugated bilirubin.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is listed as a cause of hemolytic jaundice?
questions.explanation: Causes of hemolytic jaundice include: a- Abnormal hemoglobin: sickle cell anemia and thalassemias.

questions.questionText: Physiologic neonatal jaundice, a transient condition in the first few days of life, is partly caused by increased hemolysis and partly by:
questions.explanation: It partly results from increased hemolysis and partly from immaturity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronyltransferase.

questions.questionText: How does phototherapy treat physiologic neonatal jaundice?
options: By destroying bilirubin in the skin
By converting insoluble unconjugated bilirubin to more soluble isomers
questions.correctAnswer: By converting insoluble unconjugated bilirubin to more soluble isomers
questions.explanation: Exposure to blue fluorescent light (phototherapy) helps conversion of the insoluble form of unconjugated bilirubin to the more soluble isomers that can be excreted into the bile without conjugation to glucuronic acid.

questions.questionText: Phenobarbital can be used to treat neonatal jaundice by inducing the synthesis of which enzyme?
questions.explanation: Phenobarbital may also be used in the treatment of these cases to induce the synthesis of the enzyme glucuronyltransferase.

questions.questionText: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type I, is a rare autosomal recessive disease characterized by:
questions.explanation: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type I... in which there is total deficiency of UDP-glucuronyltransferase.

questions.questionText: In Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type I, serum unconjugated bilirubin typically:
questions.explanation: In Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type I... Serum unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20 mg/dL.

questions.questionText: Patients with Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type I, typically do not respond to which treatment that is effective in Type II and neonatal jaundice?
questions.explanation: Patients [with Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type I] do not respond to phenobarbital therapy. Patients with Type II respond to large doses of phenobarbital therapy.

questions.questionText: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type II, is characterized by:
options: Defect in bilirubin excretion into bile
Increased bilirubin uptake by the liver
questions.explanation: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type II... in which there is partial deficiency of UDP-glucuronyltransferase.

questions.questionText: What is a characteristic finding in the bile of patients with Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, type II, providing evidence for the specific defect in adding the second glucuronic acid?
questions.explanation: The defect [in Crigler-Najjar Type II] is in the addition of the second glucuronic acid, as evidenced by the presence of bilirubin monoglucuronide in bile.

questions.questionText: Gilbert Syndrome is described as a benign condition caused by a defect primarily affecting:
options: Uptake of unconjugated bilirubin and conjugation pathways
Secretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile
questions.correctAnswer: Uptake of unconjugated bilirubin and conjugation pathways
questions.explanation: Gilbert Syndrome... caused by a defect in the uptake of unconjugated bilirubin by the liver and conjugation pathways.

questions.questionText: Obstructive Jaundice is caused by obstruction of the biliary passages. This leads to an increase in which form of bilirubin in the serum?
questions.explanation: This [obstruction] leads to regurgitation of conjugated bilirubin (water soluble) to the blood. Serum bilirubin increases, mainly conjugated bilirubin.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a characteristic finding in the feces of a patient with complete biliary obstruction (Obstructive Jaundice)?
options: Pale, clay colored stools (disappearance of stercobilin)
questions.correctAnswer: Pale, clay colored stools (disappearance of stercobilin)
questions.explanation: In Obstructive Jaundice... Stercobilin disappears from the feces, which produces clay colored stool.

questions.questionText: In Obstructive Jaundice, due to the blockage preventing bilirubin from reaching the intestine, what happens to urobilinogen in the urine?
questions.explanation: In Obstructive Jaundice... Urobilinogen disappears from the urine. This happens because bilirubin doesn't reach the intestine to be converted into urobilinogen.

questions.questionText: Which serum enzyme levels are typically elevated in Obstructive Jaundice due to biliary obstruction?
questions.explanation: Due to biliary obstruction, the serum levels of the enzyme alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and - glutamyltransferase (-GT) are elevated.

questions.questionText: Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with an increase in conjugated bilirubin caused by a defect in the ability of hepatocytes to secrete conjugated bilirubin into where?
questions.explanation: Dubin-Johnson is an autosomal recessive disorder, that causes an increase of conjugated bilirubin. This condition is associated with a defect in the ability of hepatocytes to secrete conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.questionText: What is a distinguishing feature of the liver histology in Dubin-Johnson Syndrome compared to Rotor Syndrome?
options: Presence of a dark pigment in the center of hepatic lobules
questions.correctAnswer: Presence of a dark pigment in the center of hepatic lobules
questions.explanation: Hepatocytes in the center of hepatic lobules contain a dark pigment in the case of Dubin-Johnson. Rotor syndrome is a similar condition, but there is no staining of the liver.

questions.questionText: Jaundice characterized by an increase in both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin is also known by what terms?
options: Physiologic neonatal jaundice or latent jaundice
questions.explanation: Both Conjugated & Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia is also called toxic hyperbilirubinemia or hepatocellular jaundice.

questions.questionText: What is the usual primary cause of hepatocellular jaundice (toxic hyperbilirubinemia)?
questions.explanation: It is usually due to viral hepatitis, but may also be caused by some toxins.

questions.questionText: In hepatocellular jaundice, why does conjugated hyperbilirubinemia occur?
options: Increased secretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile
Regurgitation of bile from the intestine
Swelling liver cells blocking the biliary canaliculi
questions.correctAnswer: Swelling liver cells blocking the biliary canaliculi
questions.explanation: In addition, liver cells usually swell blocking the biliary canaliculi, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.questionText: Which findings are typical in the urine of a patient with hepatocellular jaundice?
questions.explanation: Both urobilinogen and bilirubin appear in the urine, which becomes dark brown in color.

questions.questionText: Due to liver cell damage in hepatocellular jaundice, which serum enzymes are typically elevated?
questions.explanation: Due to liver cell damage, the serum levels of the enzymes ALT and AST and -GT are elevated. Note that ALP and GGT are also elevated but ALT and AST are more specific markers of hepatocyte damage, unlike ALP which points to biliary issues.

questions.questionText: A 62-year-old female presents with intense jaundice, upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, weight loss, pale stools, very high direct bilirubin, elevated urinary bilirubin, slightly elevated ALT, and markedly elevated ALP. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the provided case study?
questions.explanation: The case describes features strongly suggestive of obstructive jaundice: intense jaundice with high direct bilirubin and urinary bilirubin, pale stools (loss of stercobilin), and markedly elevated ALP. The pain radiating to the back and weight loss point towards a malignancy obstructing the bile duct, such as carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. Gilbert syndrome and hemolytic anemia cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Infectious hepatitis causes hepatocellular jaundice with elevated ALT/AST and both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin elevation. The findings best fit obstructive jaundice due to pancreatic cancer.
